dialogues.text: 52  47 s.46 p.53. The Macedonian peasants laugh and stare at Agnes. She get scared. Shestan looks at them with a frown.

dialogues.speaker: SHESTAN
dialogues.text: No. We aren’t here to have that kind of fun.

dialogues.speaker: MACEDONIAN PEASANT
dialogues.text: Why don’t you give us the girl? We’1l pay you handsomely. Shestan tries to control himself. Some Macedonian peasant giggle. Shestan starts talking, his voice not disguising hidden threat.

dialogues.speaker: SHESTAN
dialogues.text: We have been trusted with that girl! Nobody can touch her. Trusted! Bessa! The given word! He has now switched to Albanian. The Macedonian peasant m it, thinks for a while, then replies in bad Albanian.

dialogues.speaker: MACEDONIAN PEASANT
dialogues.text: I see! Trusted. Vera, in trust. Didn’t know.

dialogues.speaker: SHESTAN
dialogues.text: Yeah, Vera. Given word. Sacred. Both sides stare at each other. SHESTAN (cont’d) We must go now. God bless you! Shestan salutes them with hand on his heart. As they cros the river, Agnes walks behind Shestan, holding at his coa The Macedonian peasants watch them from across the river, still suspicious.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shestan’s fighters have set up fires. Through his binocul Shestan watches the Macedonians across the river, as they light fires, too.

dialogues.speaker: DOSKE
dialogues.text: I say let’s get out of here, captain. Nobody knows what gifts the night will bear.

dialogues.speaker: TOD
dialogues.text: Let’s go, captain. We’1ll manage to find our way, somehow. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CUTE
dialogues.text: Hey, what are you talking about? We have no clue what direction to take whatsoever. We risk trespassing in Greece or Macedonia once again.

dialogues.speaker: SHESTAN
dialogues.text: We stay here. Didn’t do them wrong, neither killed nor robbed them. We just got lost. He turns around, notices Agnes who is staring at him. SHESTAN (cont’d) You know what? He smiles. SHESTAN (cont’d) Let’s dance. Yes indeed: let’s dance! All night long till morn’. So we all stay awake: us and them. Halil, come here. The man called Halil approaches him quickly. SHESTAN (cont’d) Play, and we’1ll dance. Now! Play loud! Halil whistles, and two men show up, carrying a violin an tambourine. The music starts. Shestan’s men get up and st dancing by the fire. On the other bank, the Macedonians l surprised. Shestan’s men jump up in the air graciously, t kilts fluttering like wings. The Macedonians watch, while one of them leaves for the village. The dance goes on and on. Ton Now it’s the Macedonians’ turn to start dancing, on the opposite bank of the river. Their dance is similar to the Albanians’. They are gradually racing each other. The Macedonian orchestra consists of a clarinet, a violin and drum. Shestan and his fighters watch on. Now they have to wait for the Macedonians to finish dancing. They wait covered with sweat. The Macedonian dance seems to go on a on forever.

dialogues.speaker: DOSKE
dialogues.text: Captain, these guys will never stop. They are cheating. Be better to alternate our numbers, don’t you think? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: SHESTAN
dialogues.text: They’11 get tired soon, Doské, just be patient. But the Macedonians keep dancing on and on, jumping aroun screaming out of pleasure. Ton They look tired now and some of them give up and fall to ground. But new ones join the dance, and it seems it will never end. . Now the Albanians resume dancing without waiting for th Macedonians to stop. The race becomes real: which group w outperform the other? The excitement gets out of control. Agnes stays crouched, scared by the men’s fury. . The dancers’ crowd is getting thinner on both sides because some of those dancing are now down on the ground. Still, a couple of men hold on. Angry at their opponents’ perseverance, they keep moving and shouting in Macedonian Albanian.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Crack of dawn. Macedonians and Albanians lie on the groun sleeping, snoring aloud. Smoke comes out of the fires.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shestan’s fighters march through a sunlit mountain landsc Agnes follows Shestan. Shestan turns around and stares at her. The girl looks worn out.

dialogues.speaker: SHESTAN
dialogues.text: We still have to walk a lot. Agnes doesn’t reply. She gets closer and smiles at him.

dialogues.speaker: AGNES
dialogues.text: You are very handsome.

dialogues.speaker: SHESTAN
dialogues.text: You say that again and I kill you. Agnes looks at him with affection

dialogues.speaker: AGNES
dialogues.text: Are you a Muslim? Shestan answers softly

dialogues.speaker: SHESTAN
dialogues.text: Yes (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: AGNES
dialogues.text: Do you have a wife?

dialogues.speaker: SHESTAN
dialogues.text: No, why?

dialogues.speaker: AGNES
dialogues.text: How come?

dialogues.speaker: SHESTAN
dialogues.text: How come? I don’t know.

dialogues.speaker: AGNES
dialogues.text: Well, you are a man, that’s why. Shestan is confused and doesn’t know what to say.

dialogues.speaker: SHESTAN
dialogues.text: Then what?

dialogues.speaker: AGNES
dialogues.text: Nothing. Just saying... He looks at her. Agnes lowers her eyes, hides her smile. Shestan hurries away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shestan knocks on the convent’s main gate. No one seems t show up. Finally he climbs over the gate.

dialogues.speaker: SHESTAN
dialogues.text: Anybody there? No answer. Agnes waits. Shestan shouts out once again. No answer.

dialogues.speaker: AGNES
dialogues.text: No, I don’t want to stay here. Take me with you!

dialogues.speaker: SHESTAN
dialogues.text: No! This is where you’re going to stay, it’s safe, and the sisters be nice to you.

dialogues.speaker: AGNES
dialogues.text: No. They are not nice. Witches, you mean. I am scared... He motions Cute to help him. They grab Agnes and let her the wall. Mother Superior appears with three nuns but the don’t open the main gate.

dialogues.speaker: MOTHER SUPERIOR
dialogues.text: Go away, please. You cannot stay here! (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 56  51 52 53 s.50 p.57. Agnes stares at Shestan still sitting on the wall.

dialogues.speaker: SHESTAN
dialogues.text: Sister, you take her please, for God’s sake. Can’t keep her longer, we’re bound for battle. If we leave her on the road, the beast will make mincemeat of her.

dialogues.speaker: MOTHER SUPERIOR
dialogues.text: May God help you! Mother Superior, nuns and Agnes enter the convent while Shestan and his men leave.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Agnes shouts are heard.

dialogues.speaker: AGNES
dialogues.text: (off screen) No, I don’t want to stay here! I don’t want to stay with you people! The Skinny Nun leaves her room and walks stealthily in th vaulted corridor. Agnes bangs her door

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Agnes stands behind the door of her room. She hears some noise coming from the end of the corridor. Suddenly, the opens and four nuns come in, grab her, take her to the washroom, and undress her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Agnes is in Mother Superior’s office, sitting on a stool. hair is still wet, she has a new nun’s uniform, she looks nervous. After a while, the door opens and Mother Superio shows up, along with Rosseta, the Skinny Nun. Mother Supe sits down in front of Agnes, then speaks softly, witha threat.

dialogues.speaker: MOTHER SUPERIOR
dialogues.text: Sister Rosseta, Agnes will stay with us until the war is over. You will have to take care of her. May you love each other through your love in God. Mother Superior crosses herself, and says a prayer. Agnes watches them closely. 57  54 s.54 p.58.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A beautiful sunny day. A lake surrounded by an amphitheat of hills. Shestan’s fighters walking along the shoreline across a couple of signs that read: ISLAMIC PRINCEDOM OF CENTRAL ALBANIA. WE ADMIT REFUGEES FROM KOSOVO, BOSNIA AND MACEDONIA.

dialogues.speaker: WE DO NOT ADMIT REFUGEES FROM SERBIA, GREECE AND BULGARIA
dialogues.text: A procession of Catholic believers wearing icons and a primitive Christ statue walk pass them singing. Alush sta at the Christ’s statue. The procession stops on top of th hill, and lays down the cross. They seem to be waiting fo something. Worried, Alush comes to Shestan.

dialogues.speaker: ALUSH
dialogues.text: What the heck are they doing, captain?

dialogues.speaker: SHESTAN
dialogues.text: Dunno. Maybe praying.

dialogues.speaker: ALUSH
dialogues.text: I don’t think so. There’s something fishy going on there. Look at them! They look like they’ve lost their mind!

dialogues.speaker: SHESTAN
dialogues.text: Whatever. They’re not armed.

dialogues.speaker: CUTE
dialogues.text: You never know, captain.

dialogues.speaker: SHESTAN
dialogues.text: Hey, hey, wait a minute. We can’t fight the whole world here! what they are doing it’s none of our business, okay? Alush rolls a cigarette. Cute comes running.

dialogues.speaker: CUTE
dialogues.text: We got the wrong direction, captain! We’re walking in circles! Doské smiles.

dialogues.speaker: SHESTAN
dialogues.text: No, no, we’ve always been heading north. Just keep walking! Shestan is staring at the Catholic mob on top of the hill who now pray to the Christ’s statue. 58  55 56 57 s.55 p.59.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The fighters plod their way through the mud. An artillery shell whistles through the air. The shell flies towards t fighters and hits Alush Tabutgjati who’s drinking water f his canteen. Alush’s body is split in two. He expires promptly, in a pool of his blood.

dialogues.speaker: CUTE
dialogues.text: What was that, my brothers?! What was that? It came out of the blue.. God have mercy upon us!

dialogues.speaker: SHESTAN
dialogues.text: Bury him in a good place. Right there! He points at the muddy plain.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The fighters run to cross the river. The green religious with the crescent and the red Sultan flag appear on the opposite bank zigzagging above the reeds. Shestan motions men to get back into the forest at the foot of the mounta Shots are heard, then drum beats, then people yelling ”Al akhbar” but no one is to be seen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The detachment is engaged in battle. The forest scenery i wonderful, but all around we see glimpses of chaos. Men hating other men. Everybody fighting against everybody. Kus Babaj’s men hoist their Ottoman Empire flags, yell an play their drums. All are both exhausted and hysterical, enraged and some panicking. Dead and wounded everywhere. Doské, runs towards Kus Babaj’s shelter - he looks like h lost his mind altogether. He screams as he hits an enemy his bayonet. Blood splatters him red all over and covers face.

dialogues.speaker: DOSKE
dialogues.text: Come here, you scum of the earth; come here so that I can make a shish kebab of your bodies. You sonofabitch! He rushes to Kus Babaj but his guards throw him back. Dos keeps shouting. DOSKE (cont’d) Kus Babaj, I’1l go piss on your grave! You shitty bastard! (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: KUS BABAJ
dialogues.text: If I get you, I’1l have your balls crushed, you pork of an infidel!

dialogues.speaker: DOSKE
dialogues.text: But you can’t get me, you old carrion. Come here, if you have the balls! Just come here! I am invincible, I am a hero! Kus Babaj’s rebels shout in chorus:

dialogues.speaker: REBELS
dialogues.text: Give us our daddy, give us our daddy! They beat their drums angrily. Shestan’s tries to help Do but all he gets is a bayonet hit in the arm. Shestan knoc him down with the butt of his gun. Doské collapses on the ground. The beautiful meadow is now littered with the man dead and wounded.

dialogues.speaker: SHESTAN
dialogues.text: My God, everybody’s dead! Kus Babaj’s rebels withdraw and disappear behind the tree No more shots. Only moans and cries for help from the wounded. The rebels’ hysterical cackle is still heard thr the forest. The fighters withdraw too, dragging their wounded. Shestan gets to Doské and tries to find a word o courage for him. SHESTAN (cont’d) Don’t give in, Doské! We got to get back home.

dialogues.speaker: DOSKE
dialogues.text: No I won’t, my captain. I ama hero, I’m not going to die. That’s impossible. Just give me some raki. Cute gives him raki with a smile. Shestan arm is all red blood. Doské holds him tight, right on his wound. Shestan grins.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Outside the convent’s walls. Doské lies in front of the m gate. He is about to expire. Nuns are taking care of him.

dialogues.speaker: DOSKE
dialogues.text: Play the bells now that I’m still alive.. Play the bells, I say! Shestan looks at Mother Superior. She nods with her head, a young nun runs to the bells. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 60  s.58 p.61. Shestan turns his eyes towards the inner door of the conv Waits. The bells are tolling. Doské has a smile. DOSKE (cont’d) You hear? They are ringing for me! Shestan approaches Mother Superior.

dialogues.speaker: SHESTAN
dialogues.text: Please, Mother Superior. Keep him here. We cannot take him with us.

dialogues.speaker: MOTHER SUPERIOR
dialogues.text: God forgive me, we cannot. I’m so sorry.

dialogues.speaker: SHESTAN
dialogues.text: But Mother, we are from a village in the South.

dialogues.speaker: MOTHER SUPERIOR
dialogues.text: Then why don't you go bury him there?

dialogues.speaker: SHESTAN
dialogues.text: Mother, our village is far away. We don’t know when we shall be back. You see, we cannot keep a dead man with us for weeks. He’s not going to last. We have to give him a proper burial.

dialogues.speaker: MOTHER SUPERIOR
dialogues.text: He’s none of us. We cannot bury him. Shestan is getting nervous.

dialogues.speaker: SHESTAN
dialogues.text: How so? Is he not a human being? Okay, just leave him outside, so the dogs devour him. As he speaks, he catches a glimpse of two nuns showing up with a couple of bread loafs. He freezes. One of the nuns Agnes. She stops in front of him. He looks at her with affection. Agnes gives him a smile, hands him a bread loa Shestan accepts it. Agnes keeps her hands on the loaf, to him know that he must look at the bread, carefully. Shest is aware of her silent request but doesn’t understand. Ag takes the loaf away from his hands, and puts it in his ba Agnes then leaves, but she turns back once again, to have last look at Shestan. Shestan seems lost. Doské is yellin the nuns.

dialogues.speaker: DOSKE
dialogues.text: Damn you! I am dying! Play the bells! (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 61  59 s.58 p.62. DOSKE(cont'd) Don’t want to go anywhere, don’t want to stay with those witches!

dialogues.speaker: SHESTAN
dialogues.text: Watch your mouth, Doské! You can’t talk like this. We are guests here.

dialogues.speaker: DOSKE
dialogues.text: Play the bells! Christ is resurrected! I don’t go to church, Me? I go to battle! No, no, I go home. Tomorrow! One of the nuns rings the bells, energetically. Doské is and more delirious. DOSKE (cont’d) Do you hear it or not? Please brothers, take me home, please! Shestan turns his head, looking for Agnes, but he can’t s her anymore in the courtyard. The nuns have already close the main gate. Outside the convent’s walls the fighters a having their meal, and resting. Someone is already singin SHESTAN’S MAN “Albania, why don’t you resist Albania, why are you melting away, Like flowers in March Like snow in April?” The others sing along.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Agnes is in her room. The men’s singing is heard coming f outside. She prays. She looks at Shestan through the wind and cries. She follows every single move of his: the way walks, the steps he takes, his posture, the gestures he m with his hands; she tries to catch his eyes as he turns occasionally, towards the convent’s windows.

dialogues.speaker: AGNES
dialogues.text: Please forgive me, God! She falls on the bed, face forward. She prays to the wood figurine of Jesus, but she’s so badly in love with Shesta AGNES (cont’d) No, I can’t pray. Oh, God, why did you make him come here? Suddenly, there is a knock on the door. Agnes stands up abruptly. Wipes off her tears. The knock is heard again. opens the door: Mother Superior.

dialogues.speaker: LT
dialogues.text: (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 62  60 s.59 p.63. Mother Superior and Agnes sit facing each other.

dialogues.speaker: MOTHER SUPERIOR
dialogues.text: My dear, God will help you forget, if you help yourself, that is.

dialogues.speaker: AGNES
dialogues.text: I can’t, Mother. I have sinned.

dialogues.speaker: MOTHER SUPERIOR
dialogues.text: We all have. They stay silent for a while. MOTHER SUPERIOR (cont’d) If you hope time will make it easier for you, it isn’t going to happen. If you wait for a man, he might come to you, if he is not killed in the war. But if you wait for God, he will certainly come to you.

dialogues.speaker: AGNES
dialogues.text: When is God coming, Mother?

dialogues.speaker: MOTHER SUPERIOR
dialogues.text: I never ask myself that kind of question.

dialogues.speaker: AGNES
dialogues.text: Why don’t you, Mother? Is it a sin?

dialogues.speaker: MOTHER SUPERIOR
dialogues.text: No, Agnes, it’s not. It’s just that you can’t answer it. The waiting itself is the answer. Agnes looks at her, taken aback. Mother Superior stands u rather satisfied with herself, and walks out of the room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Skinny Nun’s screams are heard echoing throughout the convent. Rosetta has lost her mind, and the other nuns ar holding her firmly, so that she doesn’t hurt herself bump against the walls or the floor. Agnes watches the scene f her bedroom door. The Skinny Nun screams, and the nuns hold her above the ground, as they try to tie her up. Mother Superior orders them to follow her. Someone tries to muffle Rosseta’s screams. Two other nuns cry, upset by their friend’s breakdown. After a while, the screams can’t be heard any more. Agnes stays at the door of her room, terrified and lonely. 63  61 62 s.61 p.64.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The nuns are gathered in the refectory. Mother Superior speaks.

dialogues.speaker: MOTHER SUPERIOR
dialogues.text: I have bad news for all of us. The king is leaving. These are times of troubles. We must be prepared: anything can happen. Let’s pray to our Lord, Jesus Christ, so that he grants us protection. The nuns cross themselves and pray. MOTHER SUPERIOR (cont’d) This is why I will not tell you, because I love you all: those who want to leave - whoever they are - can do it now. Long silence. Nobody moves. MOTHER SUPERIOR (cont’d) God bless you all. Mother Superior keeps an eye on Agnes. The Skinny Nun loo at her too. But Agnes keeps her head down, without reacti to Mother Superior’s words.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shestan and his fighters are on a long and narrow road through the mountains of Northern Albania. They come acro road sign that says:

dialogues.speaker: THE CATHOLIC REPUBLIC OF LEZHA
dialogues.text: They knock the sign down and destroy it. Shestan lays his on the ground and looks for the map. he opens it, and pic up the bread loaf Agnes gave him. He shares it in half wi Cute. Cute finds a letter inside his share. He cleans it and opens it. But he cannot read. He looks around to make sure no one has seen him, then comes near Shestan and giv him the letter.

dialogues.speaker: CUTE
dialogues.text: Here, that’s what I found, inside your loaf.

dialogues.speaker: SHESTAN
dialogues.text: Inside?

dialogues.speaker: CUTE
dialogues.text: What’s in it? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: SHESTAN
dialogues.text: It’s for me.

dialogues.speaker: CUTE
dialogues.text: For you? Who wrote it? Shestan cannot find a proper answer. He has figured out t letter comes from Agnes. CUTE (cont’d) Read it to me, captain, please!

dialogues.speaker: SHESTAN
dialogues.text: This is from the Bible, Cute. The Christians’ Bible. God’s words.

dialogues.speaker: CUTE
dialogues.text: God’s? No kidding! Please read them to me, captain. Shestan reflects, but his eyes are dancing on the sheet o paper.

dialogues.speaker: SHESTAN
dialogues.text: God says: “Thou shalst not kill!”. Cute Benja reflects then shakes his head and resumes chew his bread.

dialogues.speaker: CUTE
dialogues.text: Allah says that too. But who sent you this letter?

dialogues.speaker: SHESTAN
dialogues.text: God did, Cute.

dialogues.speaker: CUTE
dialogues.text: God? Why would God write you?

dialogues.speaker: SHESTAN
dialogues.text: It is a sign, Cute.

dialogues.speaker: CUTE
dialogues.text: What is this sign, captain?! I don’t get it.

dialogues.speaker: SHESTAN
dialogues.text: God says we should go back home. Cute Benja speaks with a trembling voice.

dialogues.speaker: CUTE
dialogues.text: God is right. That’s what I say too, let’s go back to our kids. Shestan reads the letter in low voice. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: SHESTAN
dialogues.text: “God says to Moses: That man who loves a woman but who hasn’t married her yet, let him go back to her, because if he is killed in battle she will become someone else's...” The letter starts trembling in his hands.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A mosque in the background. The peasants in Turkish attir and a group of dervishes dressed in white, are listening the sermon of Ahmet the dervish. Ahmet is standing on a h boulder and keeps wagging the stick he holds in his hand. drummer crisscrosses the crowd, beating his drum. He stop when the dervish starts talking.

dialogues.speaker: AHMET
dialogues.text: Everybody’s gone, Allah, but You! You remained in the sky so that we could remain here on Earth. Father Sultan, please forgive her, because she hardly knew what she was doing; she turned down your helping hand, and preferred a German to you; a German who can’t even keep his pants up. What a shame! ! Shestan’s detachment enters the small square, holding up King’s flag. The peasants receive them coldly. The dervis stops his speech. Cute Benja approaches a group of men an salutes them.

dialogues.speaker: CUTE
dialogues.text: Greetings! Can we buy some food here?

dialogues.speaker: PEASANT
dialogues.text: No food here in the village. Only Allah can give us bread. (a3) Cute mutters something between his teeth, then approaches Shestan and talks to him in a whisper. Shestan tells him to listen to the dervish, while checking the surroundings.

dialogues.speaker: AHMET
dialogues.text: 6 Great Allah! Can’t you see the devil wants to do away with Albania? He wants the women’s veils ripped open! But a woman with her veil torn isn’t a woman anymore but a whore, and whole of Albania becomes a brothel. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 66  s.63 p.67. AHMET(cont'd) But You, 0 Great Allah, You won’t allow this to happen, and us your humble servants, we are ready for sacrifice, and we will hang these infidels and miscreants by their feet! As the dervish goes on with his speech, Shestan and his companions look at the faces of those listening. Suddenly group of religious kids dressed in white robes come out f the mosque, running threateningly, and they join the listeners, sitting down cross legged. Shestan is getting suspicious and feels the situation is turning acid. (a2) AHMET (cont’d) We don’t want an Albania with three religions, but a free Albania, with the one and only true religion, that of Mohammed’s! What must be, must be, my sons. Allah gave me this life, and if Allah requests it, I will gladly give him back. The crowd pray and psalmody: CROWD . Thank you, thank you! 0 Dervish Ahmet ! Ahmet kneels on his rock and chants his prayers with his closed. The crowd follows. Suddenly, the dervish stops hi prayer, stands, and points at the fighters.

dialogues.speaker: AHMET
dialogues.text: What are you looking for, brothers?

dialogues.speaker: SHESTAN
dialogues.text: We’d like to buy food. We pay for it in cash.

dialogues.speaker: AHMET
dialogues.text: What are you?

dialogues.speaker: SHESTAN
dialogues.text: We’re just people. Trying to join the war.

dialogues.speaker: AHMET
dialogues.text: The war is over, captain. The king ran away like a rat. Allah saved us all. Allah is great! Allahu akhbar! He gives us war and he gives us bread. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: SHESTAN _
dialogues.text: You are mistaken, 0 dervish. Men are those who make the war! Ahmet the dervish refuses to answer, climbs down the rock heads for the mosque, leaning on his walking stick. As Shestan’s fighters leave the small square, kids follow th and throw stones at them. They do not react. SHESTAN (cont’d) Let it be, they’re just kids. They don’t know what they’re doing.

dialogues.speaker: CUTE
dialogues.text: That filthy moocher! with all the stink, still talking about God! The kids have stopped at the end of the square, and keep throwing stones at the fighters, mocking them until they disappear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Inn appears in the background. The detachment of the fighters can hardly walk any longer. They are crushed wit fatigue. Cute stops and spits on the ground angrily.

dialogues.speaker: CUTE
dialogues.text: Where’s the war, captain? Seems to be running away from us all the time. Don’t think we’re getting anywhere, captain. We’re exhausted, walking night and day. Shestan answers him sharply.

dialogues.speaker: SHESTAN
dialogues.text: You asking me where the war is? How should I know, Cute?! We set off for war together. If we can’t find it, it’s nobody’s fault. And stop screaming as if they were slaughtering you.

dialogues.speaker: CUTE
dialogues.text: The hell with war! I want to go back to the village. We had to leave our homes, our wives and kids, for this damned war. But what do you know, anyway? You have neither wife nor kids. Shestan is silent. Cute keeps walking and the other fight follow him. Shestan is left behind. 68  65 66 s.65 p.69.

dialogues.speaker: DREAM, (AGNES)
dialogues.text: Sunset. Agnes the Nun is walking fast on the road. She tu her head towards the setting sun. It’s dusk already. She quickens her step, scared. On the other side of the road, sees herself, wearing Shestan’s coat. Agnes stops and loo at her. Agnes with the coat takes the hand of Agnes the N and they walk away.

dialogues.speaker: AGNES WITH THE COAT
dialogues.text: I know where he is.

dialogues.speaker: AGNES THE NUN
dialogues.text: Where?

dialogues.speaker: AGNES WITH THE COAT
dialogues.text: I can’t tell you. Follow me! Agnes the Nun doesn’t believe her. AGNES WITH THE COAT (cont’d) Look, his coat. He lost it on the way.

dialogues.speaker: AGNES THE NUN
dialogues.text: Tell me where he is!

dialogues.speaker: AGNES WITH THE COAT
dialogues.text: He is on his way to his village. We must find him before he gets there. Once he’s there, he is getting married. His mom’s found a bride for him.

dialogues.speaker: AGNES THE NUN
dialogues.text: Getting married? Agnes with the coat takes her by the hand and pulls her, Agnes the Nun resists, pulls her hand away and runs to wh she was coming from. Agnes with the coat stands in the middle of the road. It starts raining. Agnes the Nun runs away terrified and disappears. Agnes opens her eyes, realizes she has been dreaming. She catches her breath, still terrified by the dream.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Candle in hand, the Skinny Nun is at Mother Superior’s do She cries.

dialogues.speaker: SKINNY NUN
dialogues.text: Mother, open up, it’s me, Rosseta! Open the door, please! (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 69  67 s.66 p.70. Mother Superior opens the door, surprised by this late vi and asks Rosseta inside. SKINNY NUN (cont’d) Mother, may God forgive me! Sister Agnes has escaped! Mother Superior crosses herself. She fills a cup with wat and hands it to the crying Skinny Nun. She puts on her bl robe, and sits in front of her.

dialogues.speaker: MOTHER SUPERIOR
dialogues.text: Listen, sister. Nobody must know she is gone. This is God’s will. It’s not your fault. The Skinny Nun can hardly stop sobbing. Mother Superior t to her softly. MOTHER SUPERIOR (cont’d) Rosseta, sister Agnes is not going to come back. She has chosen her own way. That’s life, my dear. A long and winding road, with no end in sight. The end, though, always comes to you. The Skinny Nun, troubled by these wise words, looks up at with affection.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kus Babaj follows Shestan’s fighters through his binocula (a4)

dialogues.speaker: KUS BABAJ
dialogues.text: Come back, my son! 0 Allah! They are so tired. Tell them to come back and get some rest at the inn! Suddenly, bells start ringing at the convent. Kus Babaj swears. KUS BABAJ (cont'd) Shut up! Damned whores! what’s the fuck with these bells now?

dialogues.speaker: GUARD
dialogues.text: It’s the infidels’ Bayram, Kus Babaj. Kus Babaj points his binoculars at the fighters.

dialogues.speaker: KUS BABAJ
dialogues.text: Come back, my sons, come rest at last before the big sleep... (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 70  68 69 s.67 p.71. POV from the binoculars: the fighters walking in line, th Shestan Verdha’s handsome profile. KUS BABAJ (cont'd) Are you still trying to run away from me, my son? 0 Allah, I pray You, tell them to spend the night at the inn, they’re so tired! Through his binoculars, he sees Shestan give a suspicious look at the desert plains surrounding the inn.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The fighters have now left the inn behind. Cute Benja sto stamps his feet on the ground and yells.

dialogues.speaker: CUTE
dialogues.text: What do we do now, captain Shestan? Can’t walk no more. Enough. The detachment stops. Shestan turns his head and stares a the inn already wrapped in darkness. Signals his companio to walk back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A man with a lantern greets the fighters at the inn’s gat He is Ali, the inn-keeper. Shestan takes the lantern from hand and raises it to the man’s face, Ali brings up a smi

dialogues.speaker: SHESTAN
dialogues.text: What is your name?

dialogues.speaker: ALI
dialogues.text: Ali.

dialogues.speaker: SHESTAN
dialogues.text: We’1ll spend the night here. We need your word we’re going to be safe. The inn-keeper marks it, showing surprise at Shestan’s request.

dialogues.speaker: ALI
dialogues.text: You have my word! Come inside! He puts his hand over his heart and bows.

dialogues.speaker: SHESTAN
dialogues.text: Give us something to eat and then prepare our beds! Our animals have to be attended to as well. Here’s some money. He produces some coins and drops them in Ali’s hand. The fighters enter the inn. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 71  70 71 s.69 p.72. Ali motions his two sons to go feed the horses. Shestan g back to the inn’s gate and checks the road. He then goes on a tree stump and starts rolling a cigarette. He looks downhearted. Stares at the moon reflections upon the pond Lights his cigarette and starts smoking. Sleep is closing down on him. He goes to the pond and splashes some water his face. Then, he climbs on the roof. Up there he can se the road and the inn’s courtyard. The need to sleep is becoming a torture. He wakes up with a jolt when the cigarette burns his fingers. Stands up, listens to the silence. Only the frogs’ chorus can be heard. He lies dow the roof. He’s asleep.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On the roof, Shestan is sleeping under the stars, covered with his coat. Suddenly, Cute Benja’s scary coarse scream heard, like a diabolic cackle:

dialogues.speaker: CUTE
dialogues.text: We’re getting slaughtered, brothers! Drums are heard, as in the Muslim rebels’ rituals. Then a rooster sings. Head with red crest and beak opening and closing. Shestan opens his eyes. The sky is full of stars. He hear drum beats. He is still in his dream. He stands up. Right the rooftop he sees the shadow of a man with a long knife his hand, shining in the moonlight, coming at him.

dialogues.speaker: SHESTAN
dialogues.text: Ali, is that you? Ali the innkeeper screams like mad and jumps on Shestan. two men roll over fighting on the roof. Then fly down sti fighting in the air. The two bodies land heavily on the haystack. Ali is on top but doesn't move anymore, while Shestan, underneath, has his eyes wide open, having a unc look. Slowly, he closes them. EXT. AGNES’ HOUSE. NIGHT. 71 Still wearing the nun’s robe, Agnes knocks on the door at house. Dogs bark. One of them - her dog - comes to her recognizes her. The door opens, and light from a burning candle lets somebody’s face be seen.

dialogues.speaker: AGNES FATHER
dialogues.text: Who is it? Come in, please!

dialogues.speaker: AGNES
dialogues.text: Daddy, it’s me, Agnes!

dialogues.speaker: AGNES FATHER
dialogues.text: who? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: AGNES
dialogues.text: Me, Agnes, father! The man freezes. He brings the candle closer to his daughter’s face. Agnes removes the scarf. The man now recognizes her. He is shocked. Steps back, and turns his on her. Agnes opens her arms towards her father. AGNES (cont’d) Father, I am back! The father, although moved, raises a hand in denial.

dialogues.speaker: FATHER
dialogues.text: Go back to where you came from, girl! Agnes, tearful, takes a few steps towards him. The man tu to her, threatening.

dialogues.speaker: AGNES FATHER
dialogues.text: Get off my door, I say!

dialogues.speaker: AGNES
dialogues.text: Daddy, please, for God’s sake, let me in! She falls on her knees. The man goes somewhere inside, an then reappears with a rifle. Agnes sits with her head lowered.

dialogues.speaker: AGNES FATHER
dialogues.text: Don’t tempt me, girl! Go back where you came from!

dialogues.speaker: AGNES
dialogues.text: Father, I can’t go back there. I don’t want to, I can’t live with them. Please, don’t do this to me! Her father has lost his mind. Agnes doesn’t budge, even though the gun’s barrel looms over her head. Agnes’s moth has appeared on the threshold, and crosses herself. Agnes looks at her.

dialogues.speaker: AGNES FATHER
dialogues.text: Go away, I say. In God’s name, go away. I don’t have a daughter to receive in my house. Go away, while it’s still dark and people are asleep. He’s tearful too. Agnes doesn’t move. Her father raises t gun and shoots at the ground in front of her. Gravels sprinkle everywhere. Dogs bark. Agnes is startled, but sh still refuses to move. The father brusquely pushes his wi aside, and closes the door. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 73  72 73 74 75 s.71 p.74. Agnes stays for a while on her knees, then stands up and to the well. She takes some water, washes off her tears. dog comes back to her, questioningly. EXT. AGNES’ VILLAGE. NIGHT 72 Agnes walks through her village. She is scared, dogs bark roosters protest and cackle. She stops walking and looks around.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Agnes walks fast on a deserted country road.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The sun is coming slowly out. Shestan’s fighters’ severed heads fly out through the inn’s main entry door and fall the mud, with the rebels screaming. Drums are being playe and Kus Babaj’s men are dancing and singing around the he KUS BABAJ’S MEN “we set off for paradise, but ended up in hell, Albania, you whore, you’ve poisoned us all. Five hundred years of fun, what do you want now, boys. Albania, you whore, you’ve poisoned us all. In the inn’s courtyard Shestan sits in an armchair, holdi his wounded belly. Kus Babaj stands besides him playing w his rosary.

dialogues.speaker: KUS BABAJ
dialogues.text: Your friends are gone to paradise. Shestan looks at the pile of severed heads.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kus Babaj and Shestan Verdha ride the carousel. Kus Babaj stares at him with desire and talks to him affectionately

dialogues.speaker: KUS BABAJ
dialogues.text: Are you Christian?

dialogues.speaker: SHESTAN
dialogues.text: No. Muslim.

dialogues.speaker: KUS BABAJ
dialogues.text: Really? I thought you were Christian. My lover Vasilakis was a Christian. Do you know what happened to him? They killed him, they sliced him through the nipple. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 74  s.75 p.75. Silence. The carousel moves around whining and making all sorts of cracking sounds. Kus Babaj sighs and seems about cry.

dialogues.speaker: SHESTAN
dialogues.text: What did you want to tell me?

dialogues.speaker: KUS BABAJ
dialogues.text: What is it that you wanted?

dialogues.speaker: SHESTAN
dialogues.text: We were looking for war.

dialogues.speaker: KUS BABAJ
dialogues.text: What war?

dialogues.speaker: SHESTAN
dialogues.text: The real one. Kus Babaj laughs out loud, flashing his gold teeth.

dialogues.speaker: KUS BABAJ
dialogues.text: There never was a real one. Man goes to war in order to fool himself. Or maybe because he doesn’t know what to do with his life. Or because he can’t stay home. Look at me: do you know why I roam the country like this?

dialogues.speaker: SHESTAN
dialogues.text: No, but it’s one of the questions I wanted...

dialogues.speaker: KUS BABAJ
dialogues.text: Because I have nothing left. My heart is broken. I am a lonely man. Are you in love? (a5) Shestan doesn’t answer. He stands up, unaware of the spinning carousel. KUS BABAJ (cont'd) Where are you going? Wait! Shestan jumps off the platform. Kus Babaj follows him wit his eyes, and calls out to him. KUS BABAJ (cont'd) Why waste your life? You are going to get killed, you pretty thing... Shestan walks away and passes Kus Babaj’s rebels sitting cross legged around a fire. Kus Babaj, still riding the carousel, has tears in his eyes. 75  76 77 78 s.76 p.76. DREAM (SHESTAN). SHESTAN’S HOUSE. 76 The roosters are singing. Shestan is sitting next to the fireplace in his house, wearing a white shirt. A big brea loaf is being baked on the cinders. AGNES shows up at the door, dressed like a nun. She smiles. She carries in her hands a steaming hot water basin. She approaches Shestan looking at each other in the eyes. Shestan washes his han and his face. He then takes Agnes’s hand, and she kneels to him. Shestan lowers her black robe, and she appears na Shestan slowly washes her face, her body, her legs. AGNES picks the bread loaf from the hearth, blows off the ashes clean it, breaks the bread and gives a piece to Shestan, stares and smiles at her.. EXT. NUNS’ CONVENT. DAWN. 77 The nuns walk out of the convent’s gate and walk up the d road in procession. The bells toll.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Agnes walks on a country road. She arrives at a crossroad where people are going up to the Hill of Holy Grave. She in the distance the procession of nuns coming towards her She kneels on the side of the road and waits for them. (a6) The procession of nuns is about to pass Agnes still kneeling on the side of the road, when Mother Superior suddenly notices her and tells the nuns to halt. Agnes th herself flat on the ground, asking for forgiveness. Mothe Superior looks at her, then makes sure the other nuns are listening. Then she speaks:

dialogues.speaker: MOTHER SUPERIOR
dialogues.text: Now, now, my child, come... Rise up. Agnes gets on her knees, head bowed. MOTHER SUPERIOR (cont’d) Why don’t you go back home?

dialogues.speaker: AGNES
dialogues.text: I can’t, Mother. I have sinned.

dialogues.speaker: MOTHER SUPERIOR
dialogues.text: Do you remember what I told you once? Silence MOTHER SUPERIOR (cont’d) I told you you had to choose between the love of God and that of a man. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 76  79 s.78 p.77. MOTHER SUPERIOR(cont'd) That if you wait for God, he will certainly come to you, but if you wait for a man, it isn’t going to happen, even if he isn’t killed in the war. Do you remember?

dialogues.speaker: AGNES
dialogues.text: Yes, mother. Mother Superior speaks with a soothing humbleness:

dialogues.speaker: MOTHER SUPERIOR
dialogues.text: Poor Agnes, you see, I - myself - isn't much in the eyes of the Almighty, and I didn't want to make a prediction. I am not a soothsayer. I am too small a being on this earth to have the power to know what will happen in the future. Only God knows what will happen, and He shall prevail. We all put our faith in Him. Maybe God spoke through my words when He tried to warn you, and this is why what I told you cannot be a prediction. Agnes looks defeated but doesn’t move. She didn’t quite c what Mother Superior is getting at... MOTHER SUPERIOR (cont’d) Of course I know, my poor child, you didn’t want this to happen, but it has happened. That’s the way it goes in life. I have heard that a party of Albanian Muslims from the village of Mokér has been slaughtered about twenty kilometers from here in an ambush, inside some inn. It was a massacre, I was told: none of them survived. I believe we are talking about the same people. I am really sorry. Then Mother Superior just walks away towards the Sacred h followed by her nuns and some people. Agnes is completely destroyed. A crowd passes by, she doesn't move for a whil Some wind blows. Time passes while she stays curled up in dust. Finally she rises. She seems elsewhere. She follows the c like a ghost. Her robe is gray with dust

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The hill shimmers under the sun. Two different procession join each other on the top of the hill. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 77  s.79 p.78. The first is composed of Catholic peasants from St. Mary’ village with a large cross carried by several people. The other procession comes from the neighboring Muslim villag Zall Her, hoisting the green flag with the moon crescent. Agnes gets in the crowd and hides behind the nuns. On top of the hill, a Muslim old timer points to a large rock, half buried in the ground. There’s an Arabic inscription on one side of the rock, and a Latin inscript on the other side. He points to the sky. (a7)

dialogues.speaker: OLD MAN
dialogues.text: Listen to me, all of you! This is the Holy Grave of Saint Doruntina, a saint for Muslims and Christians! Ahmet the dervish will be buried alive and will stay inside his grave until sunset. We shall dig him out only then, and if Allah helped him stay alive, we’ll erect the mosque right here. Nobody will have to fight about it any more! Now it’s up to you, Christians to select one of your kind, to be sacrificed and see whether he’1l make it until sunset. If nobody wants to be sacrificed, then go back to your place and ring your bells, and let everyone know that a mosque is going to be built right here, with Allah’s help! Three men are already digging the grave for Ahmet. He sit the grave and waits: he prays, rosary in hand. The Cathol side remains silent. The old Muslim yells out loud. OLD MAN (cont’d) Isn’t there anyone among you Christians, who is ready to give up his life for his God? Silence. (a8) Agnes turns to the assembly and speaks out a loud voice.

dialogues.speaker: AGNES
dialogues.text: Listen to me, people, Muslims and Christians! Take me to the cross: I want to be crucified! Let my father know that his daughter followed God’s way, let everyone here or above know this! The nuns can hardly believe their ears. Agnes’ decision i final. Everybody else is talking. Ahmet the dervish, look incredulous. The Catholic crowd starts praying, in chorus They kneel. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 78  80 81 s.79 p.79. Agnes is trembling. The nuns kneel in front of the statue Jesus and pray. Everybody is taken by a frenzy of prayer. Christian side repeats in chorus: “Amen, Amen”. Agnes tak few steps forward and looks at the assembly. Mother Super shakes her head, looking away in apparent disapproval. Ag crosses herself and covers her face, so that nobody can s her pain. The cross is laid down. The old man speaks.

dialogues.speaker: OLD MAN
dialogues.text: When everything is ready, we’ll leave them alone with their God. At sunset, it will be over: if the dervish has survived, we shall build the mosque; if the woman has survived, you may build your church. If they’re both dead, nothing’s going to be erected. Murmurs. Ahmet the dervish is given some water. The Skinn Nun takes water to Agnes. Agnes recognizes her, and smile Drinks water from her hand.

dialogues.speaker: SKINNY NUN
dialogues.text: I’1l watch you. Live on, sister May God be with you! This is a great day! She hugs her. Agnes lies down on the cross. Ahmet the der climbs down the open grave. His people encourage him by saying their prayers around the hole in the ground. He li down. People throw earth on him. He is seen smiling. Hamm are heard driving the spikes into the cross. The Catholic people cross themselves and pray. Some nuns cry. Birds ar singing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (a9) Shestan appears on the village’s square. He enters t mosque. Nobody’s inside. Shestan lies on the rug. The muezzin’s steps are heard, as he comes down the stairs. H very young.

dialogues.speaker: SHESTAN
dialogues.text: I come from the battle. Everyone was killed.

dialogues.speaker: MUEZZIN
dialogues.text: Did you kill anyone?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The hill shimmering under the sun. The cross with the crucified Agnes is visible on the summit. The crowd has l A man smoking tobacco sits near the hole where they burie Ahmet the dervish. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 79  s.81 p.80. The Skinny Nun is on her knees in front of the cross, praying. On the cross, Agnes doesn’t budge. Her head has fallen on her chest from exhaustion. The Muslim man bends over the pile of earth, and places his ear on the ground, listening. He turns to the Skinny Nun, exhilarated.

dialogues.speaker: MUSLIM MAN
dialogues.text: He’s singing! The man is singing! That’s what I call a brave man may Allah give him strength! The Skinny Nun gives the man an astonished look.

dialogues.speaker: SKINNY NUN
dialogues.text: Singing? How come?

dialogues.speaker: MUSLIM MAN
dialogues.text: He does sing, by Allah! Come! Come, and listen to him! Horrified, the Skinny Nun approaches the dervish’s grave. kneels then leans her cheek against the freshly moved ear She can’t hear a thing. MUSLIM MAN (cont'd) Can you hear it?

dialogues.speaker: SKINNY NUN
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: MUSLIM MAN
dialogues.text: Well, listen better!

dialogues.speaker: SKINNY NUN
dialogues.text: No song, nothing. Can’t hear a thing.

dialogues.speaker: MUSLIM MAN
dialogues.text: What are you talking about!? He was singing only a minute ago! Get away from there! The Muslim man almost pushes her away. The Skinny Nun sta up, trembling. The Muslim man places his ear against the grave. Stays in that position for a while, then stands up looking cheerful. Starts shouting. MUSLIM MAN (cont'd) He is singing again! The Skinny Nun looks at him, skeptical.

dialogues.speaker: SKINNY NUN
dialogues.text: If you say so. The man rolls a cigarette, content. The Skinny Nun goes t the cross and talks to Agnes. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 80  s.81 p.81. SKINNY NUN (cont’d) Agnes, Agnes, sister! Can you hear me? The man stares at Agnes, also waiting for a reaction. Agn moves her head a little. The Skinny Nun takes a breath of relief. Agnes is still alive. The Muslim man picks up the water jug to drink, then looks at the Skinny Nun. He gets comes to her and hands her the jug. The Skinny Nun refuse The man looks at her, surprised. He shrugs and walks away still carrying the jug. He drinks, then sits cross legged and starts counting the beads on his rosary. Ton The sun is now at its highest. Three people from the Musl village and three from the Catholic - among which Mother Superior - have come to check the buried Dervish and the crucified Agnes. Agnes is still alive, but very pale. Blo has trickled along her limbs to the ground. The Skinny Nu cries softly. Agnes opens her eyes, stares at them, then dazzled by the sun, looks dizzily down at the crying Skin Nun.

dialogues.speaker: MUSLIM MAN
dialogues.text: She’s alive.

dialogues.speaker: CATHOLIC MAN
dialogues.text: Yes, she’s alive.

dialogues.speaker: SKINNY NUN
dialogues.text: Of course she’s alive! The Skinny Nun approaches Mother Superior. SKINNY NUN (cont’d) Mother, she’s in pain, we should bring her down from the cross. It’s a terrible pain. Maybe we should stop this now.

dialogues.speaker: MOTHER SUPERIOR
dialogues.text: Now is too late, sister. May God give her life! They move to the grave where Ahmet the dervish is buried. first man places his ear against the earth and listens carefully.

dialogues.speaker: MUSLIM MAN
dialogues.text: He’s alive. The Catholic man listens too.

dialogues.speaker: CATHOLIC MAN
dialogues.text: Yes, he’s alive. That’s weird! (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 81  82 s.81 p.82. The Muslim doesn’t like these words.

dialogues.speaker: MUSLIM MAN
dialogues.text: Why weird? Of course he’s alive! We heard him sing! Ahmet the dervish has been buried alive many times when he served the Sultan as a soldier, in the Arabian Desert. The Catholics look at each other, annoyed, then the two groups leave and head for different directions. The Skinn Nun stands facing the cross, without moving. The birds ar singing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Inside the mosque, the muezzin attends Shestan’s wounds. damps his lips with a wet cloth.

dialogues.speaker: SHESTAN
dialogues.text: I put myself in your hands. The muezzin smiles.

dialogues.speaker: MUEZZIN
dialogues.text: You put yourself in Allah’s hands. Shestan produces Agnes’ letter, and shows it to the muezz

dialogues.speaker: SHESTAN
dialogues.text: Who is Moses? The muezzin reads.

dialogues.speaker: MUEZZIN
dialogues.text: Musa the prophet, a great fighter and a very wise man. Used to take orders from Allah. Shestan looks stunned.

dialogues.speaker: SHESTAN
dialogues.text: Orders from Allah?!

dialogues.speaker: MUEZZIN
dialogues.text: Yes indeed. Now listen, good man! Don’t ever come back to this place.

dialogues.speaker: SHESTAN
dialogues.text: Why? The muezzin doesn’t answer. He just stares at him. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: MUEZZIN
dialogues.text: And don’t take the road. Go through to the hill. It’s easy to spot: they’ve crucified a woman there, a nun, this very morning.

dialogues.speaker: SHESTAN
dialogues.text: A nun, you said?

dialogues.speaker: MUEZZIN
dialogues.text: I don’t know. Her father, they say, wanted her to be crucified.

dialogues.speaker: SHESTAN
dialogues.text: Her father?

dialogues.speaker: MUEZZIN
dialogues.text: He rejected her. Shestan is already out of the mosque. The muezzin follows him.

dialogues.speaker: SHESTAN
dialogues.text: I owe you one, my friend! Shestan is already out of sight.

dialogues.speaker: MUEZZIN
dialogues.text: May Allah be with you!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shestan runs around the hill. Goes past a fence where somebody has hanged black clothes to dry. Picks them up making sure nobody’s watching, and runs away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (a10) A woman figure dressed in black, carrying wood on h back, is painfully climbing up the hill. It is Shestan disguised as a Muslim woman in wide breeches, with a blac veil on her head. He finally sees the cross with the huma figure on it. He gets closer to the top. The Muslim man on guard at the Dervish’s tomb walks to th cross, where the Skinny Nun is watching over Agnes. He st and stares at Agnes, who is covered in blood. Shakes his in wonder, awe and incomprehension.

dialogues.speaker: MUSLIM MAN
dialogues.text: My God! That’s what it is, when you lose your mind: you become a Christian! (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 83  s.84 p.84. The Skinny Nun looks at him, angered. The man is embarras by the Skinny Nun’s gaze, and leaves. He goes sit, cross legged, near the Dervish’s tomb, and sulks. Shestan Verdha shows up on the top of the hill. He can’t recognize the face of the person on the cross. He sees a sitting at the base of the cross, and a few yards away, a smoking his pipe next to a pile of fresh earth. The man s him, stands up and yells at him. MUSLIM MAN (cont'd) Hey, old woman, go away! Hurry up! Go away! This is a sacred place! Shestan approaches humbly, throws the wood away, and pull out a large knife to the man’s throat. (a11)

dialogues.speaker: SHESTAN
dialogues.text: Don’t say a word, or you die! The Muslim man stops dead and nods. Shestan motions to th cross. SHESTAN (cont’d) You do understand? The man nods, frightened. Shestan ties up his hands with rope, and then stuffs his mouth with the veil. The Skinny recognizes Shestan. Shestan runs to the cross, grabs the ladder and places it against the cross. Climbs up and uncovers the girl’s face. Agnes. He leans his head agains her chest. She is still alive. Sees the nails through her wrists.

dialogues.speaker: AGNES
dialogues.text: Who are you?

dialogues.speaker: SHESTAN
dialogues.text: What have you done? He produces his knife, grabs a rock from the ground, and back to the cross. Starts using the knife and the rock, l a lever, to pull out the nails. Agnes moans.

dialogues.speaker: SKINNY NUN
dialogues.text: You can’t do this! Agnes chose the cross herself! I am here to watch on her. Please, leave her alone! This is sacrilege! He keeps working on the nails. Agnes moans in pain. She doesn’t recognize him. Shestan removes the nails. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 84  s.84 p.85. SKINNY NUN (cont'd) Why are you doing this? I took an oath, with God. This is sacrilege! (a12)

dialogues.speaker: SHESTAN
dialogues.text: God? Which God? Tell me! What kind of god is He? Is He the god who brought you here? Who told you to do this?

dialogues.speaker: AGNES
dialogues.text: (delirious) Who are you who takes so many forms? What is your name?

dialogues.speaker: SHESTAN
dialogues.text: Please, tell me yours!

dialogues.speaker: AGNES
dialogues.text: (half conscious) Agnes! Agnes is my name.

dialogues.speaker: SHESTAN
dialogues.text: Agnes. I’ve seen you in a dreanm...

dialogues.speaker: AGNES
dialogues.text: (half conscious) Yes. Me too. With the Skinny Nun’s help, Shestan lays Agnes on the gro Shestan takes his water bottle, and pours a few drops on Agnes’s dried lips. Agnes is thirsty, wants to drink. Agn is shaking. She looks at him, Shestan holds her wrapped i his arms. Agnes motions towards the grave where Ahmet is buried. AGNES (cont’d) There’s a man buried there... Shestan does not understand. Agnes points to the pile of fresh earth. He cannot believe her.

dialogues.speaker: SKINNY NUN
dialogues.text: It’s a sin, isn't it? A man, buried alive? Shestan grabs her by the arm, and has her sit on the grou by the grave. Agnes is shaking from shock. The tied up Mu man stares, terrified. Shestan unties him, and talks to h harshly, with his knife against the man’s throat.

dialogues.speaker: SHESTAN
dialogues.text: Dig the man out of the grave! (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 85  5.84 p.86. The man is so scared he can hardly move.

dialogues.speaker: MUSLIM MAN
dialogues.text: I can’t. It’s sacrilege! Shestan grabs him by the throat and shouts.

dialogues.speaker: SHESTAN
dialogues.text: Dig, I say, or you die! The man, out of fear, suddenly starts digging very fast t soft earth with his bare hands. Shestan helps him out digging with the knife. He finally reaches the burried ma still alive, smeared with mud. Shestan pulls him out from grave. Removes the mud from his face, and notices how pal the man is. SHESTAN (cont’d) He’s breathing, he’s breathing, he’s alive!

dialogues.speaker: MUSLIM MAN
dialogues.text: Of course he’s alive! I heard him singing!

dialogues.speaker: SHESTAN
dialogues.text: Singing?

dialogues.speaker: MUSLIM MAN
dialogues.text: Yes, he was singing a sura from the Koran. Shestan orders him to give the man some water. The Skinny approaches Agnes and hugs her. Shestan talks to the Muslim man.

dialogues.speaker: SHESTAN
dialogues.text: If anyone asks you what happened here, you’1l tell them God’s Angel showed up and took them away. Do you understand?

dialogues.speaker: MUSLIM MAN
dialogues.text: Yes, yes, of course, I will...

dialogues.speaker: SHESTAN
dialogues.text: Say it! The man repeats the words, frightened.

dialogues.speaker: MUSLIM MAN
dialogues.text: An-Angel- of -God-came-down-and-took- them-away!

dialogues.speaker: SHESTAN
dialogues.text: Good. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 86  85 86 87 s.84 p.87 Shestan takes Agnes in his arms, and starts walking. SHESTAN (cont’d) Please, stay alive! The Skinny Nun and the Muslim Man remain on the hill top staring at them as they go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shestan hides with Agnes in a wheat field gilded by the setting sun. He picks a couple of ears, crushes them, and gives them to Agnes. Agnes tries to chew, but swallows wi visible pain. He gives her some water from the gourd, the some more fresh wheat to eat. Agnes looks at him, with admiration. Shestan stares at the sun, about to set. Catt bells are heard, as their herd is coming home from the meadows. Shestan stands up, and sees the sheep scattered over the plateau. A shepherd on a mule whistles at the sh

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shestan puts a crown made out of wheat on Agnes’ head.

dialogues.speaker: SHESTAN
dialogues.text: Agnes, now you are a Saint Shestan, dressed up like a shepherd, pulls a mule on whic Agnes can be seen, her head covered with a long white sca held by a tiara of wheat. She looks like a holy woman, ta part in a ritual. They walk by a field where peasants are working. The peasants respectfully stop and watch them pa by.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They go through a Christian village. People first look at them with curiosity, and children run after them. Some wo start praying, then kneel when they see the wounds. Two o ladies approach Shestan and give him water, plums and fig They cross themselves.

dialogues.speaker: WOMEN
dialogues.text: Glory to Jesus Christ, our Lord. Now and forever. Where are you heading to, young man? Shestan tries to cross himself, a little confused, and doesn’t know what to answer right away. He stops the mule looks at the small crowd surrounding him: they are all curious.

dialogues.speaker: SHESTAN
dialogues.text: This woman is holy! She is a Saint! (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 87  88 89 90 s.87 p.88. People watch him, still incredulous. Shestan approaches A on the mule, removes her scarf and shows them her wrists ankles, with the nail wounds. Stigmata! People are flabbergasted, some women scream out of wonder one of them faints. They all fall on their knees, and pra SHESTAN (cont'd) This girl was sanctified on the cross. I am now taking her home, to her parents, to the village of Shen Pal Already, they all want to touch Agnes’s robe. One by one follow Shestan and the Saint woman on the road.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Later, on the road. Now, the procession with Agnes, the S woman, already counts more than a hundred people. It has changed into a magnificent ritual. Shestan looks at the h line of people. Cannot believe his eyes. Now he is sure i will be easier to take Agnes back home. It worked. EXT. AGNES’ VILLAGE. SUNSET. 89 The procession with the Saint reaches Shen Pal, Agnes' village, by sunset. The crowd is even bigger now and they chanting:

dialogues.speaker: CROWD
dialogues.text: Glory to our Lord, Jesus! Now and for ever! Shestan is moved by what he sees and hears. He looks at A who sits, hieratic and fearless like a veiled statue, on mule. EXT. AGNES’ HOUSE. COURTYARD. SUNSET. 90 The long procession stops in front of Agnes’s house. Shes helps Agnes get off the mule. He uncovers her face. Peopl recognize her, and express their admiration:

dialogues.speaker: CROWD
dialogues.text: Agnes has been sanctified by our Lord! Agnes is God sent! Our Agnes has become a Saint! Agnes’s family has come out of the house: father, mother sisters and brothers. Agnes enters the courtyard majestically, then crosses herself and kneels. Everyone c see the Stigmata on her wrists and ankles. The crowd knee (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 88  91 92 93 94 s.90 p.89. Her mother has now recognized her, and she is stupefied. father approaches her, astounded, sees his daughter's pal face, the dried blood on her wounds. Shestan talks to Agn parents. Everyone listens in silence.

dialogues.speaker: SHESTAN
dialogues.text: Agnes was sanctified on the cross. This was the Almighty’s will. She now has come home to see her mother and father, and to give her blessing to all you people. We are tired, we had a long journey. Nobody says a word, people pray: they are witnessing a miracle. Agnes’ father looks at Shestan. Shestan looks ba at him. Agnes keeps her eyes closed and tears roll down h cheeks. Everybody (including Agnes’ parents) have fallen their knees in front of Agnes, and pray. Agnes looks at h mother through her tears. Then, she stands up and majestically enters the house. All her family follows her inside. The door remains open. Around the house hundreds people now sit and pray. They have lit up hundreds of candles. Shestan rolls a cigarette. INT. AGNES’ HOUSE. WOMENS’ ROOM. NIGHT. 91 Agnes is sitting with her back to the fireplace. Glimpses the fire crown her head and the reflection of the light o her white clothes give her complexion an inner brightness Her mother and sisters are sitting in front of her at som distance, showing her an unusual respect. The tabletop an furniture are crowded with presents and flowers. Many wom are now in the room. Everybody looks at her with admirati One of the women brings Agnes her little baby for benediction, she touches its forehead. INT. AGNES’ HOUSE. MENS’ ROOM. NIGHT. 92 There are only men around the open fire. Agnes father off his tobacco box to the guests. In this room the tabletop furniture are also crowded with presents. No one talks. Everyone in the room stares at him with due respect to th father of Agnes, as if waiting for an explanation of what just happened to his daughter. Agnes’ father proudly igno a few suspicious looks, now he has recovered his honor. EXT. AGNES’ HOUSE. NIGHT. 93 Shestan is taking off the mule’s saddle. Hundreds of cand light up the faces of people praying in front of the hous INT. AGNES’ HOUSE. WOMENS’ ROOM. NIGHT. 94 Agnes mother crosses herself and talks to Agnes. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: AGNES MOTHER
dialogues.text: Agnes, are you going to stay home?

dialogues.speaker: AGNES
dialogues.text: No, mother.

dialogues.speaker: AGNES MOTHER
dialogues.text: Where are going, then?

dialogues.speaker: AGNES
dialogues.text: Far away, mother.

dialogues.speaker: AGNES MOTHER
dialogues.text: What are you going to do?

dialogues.speaker: AGNES
dialogues.text: I have to meet other people. Agnes’ mother looks at her, in pain.

dialogues.speaker: AGNES MOTHER
dialogues.text: Are you going to have a house?

dialogues.speaker: AGNES
dialogues.text: Maybe, mother.

dialogues.speaker: AGNES MOTHER
dialogues.text: Are you going to see us again? Agnes looks at her, she can’t hold her tears.

dialogues.speaker: AGNES
dialogues.text: I don’t know, mother. They embrace each other. EXT. AGNES’ HOUSE. NIGHT. 95 There are hundreds of candles lit all over the place, in garden, on the roof, everywhere. It is like a holy night. People have gathered around open fires and talk in a low voice. Many of them pray. It sounds like a wide murmur. Shestan is feeding the mule with oats. He tries to see wh is going on inside Agnes’ house. He only sees many people getting in and out, but cannot see Agnes. EXT. AGNES’ HOUSE. NIGHT. 96 Shestan is sleeping peacefully, coiled up inside a warm blanket. Around him, people are still praying. The flames the candles dance under a light breeze. 90  97 98 s.97 p.91. EXT. AGNES’ HOUSE. NIGHT. 97 Agnes’ father walks fast towards where Shestan is sleepin With an oil lamp in his hands he tries to scan Shestan’s face. It seems he wants to know who is this man who is ta his daughter from him, and at the same time has given him back his honor. He cannot quite make it out. He stays the for a while, just looking at Shestan asleep. Then he lays some bread, cheese and water near Shestan. He then sits a crosses his legs, waiting for him to wake up. EXT. AGNES’ HOUSE. SUNRISE. 98 Sun is rising up. Roosters are heard everywhere. Shestan opens his eyes. He wakes up. He cannot believe his eyes. front of his face sits Agnes’ father, cross-legged.

dialogues.speaker: SHESTAN
dialogues.text: Good morning! Agnes father doesn’t reply. He just hands him his tobacco pouch. Shestan takes it and rolls a cigarette.

dialogues.speaker: AGNES FATHER
dialogues.text: I want you to tell me something.

dialogues.speaker: SHESTAN
dialogues.text: Go ahead.

dialogues.speaker: AGNES FATHER
dialogues.text: What has really happened to my daughter? I think you know it. Shestan stands up, looks at him and starts to harness the mule’s saddle. Agnes’ father stares at him. Shestan pulls mule toward the house. Agnes’ father goes after him. AGNES FATHER (cont'd) Tell me what happened to my daughter... Shestan doesn’t answer him, he just pulls the mule to Agn house through the courtyard. AGNES FATHER (cont'd) Why don’t you tell me? I am her father... Shestan just holds the mule. Agnes shows up on the doorst her mother and other women following her. They kneel. She helps Agnes getting on the mule. Her mother and sisters c Agnes’ father stands behind them. Shestan and Agnes on th mule now leave. The crowd follows them in procession. 91  99 100 101 s.99 p.92. EXT. AGNES’ VILLAGE. MORNING. 99 Agnes and Shestan, who pulls the mule, leave Agnes’ villa Dozens of people do not follow them, they cross themselve and kneel. They wave to the saint. They pray, watching th couple fade away in the morning light.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Agnes has stopped the mule. She looks around.

dialogues.speaker: AGNES
dialogues.text: I have to change my clothes. Shestan looks at her, surprised. Agnes doesn’t make a sin move. After a second, Shestan understands she doesn’t wan him to look at her.

dialogues.speaker: SHESTAN
dialogues.text: Oh, yes.. I won’t look at you. He moves to the other side of the mule and turns his back her. Agnes takes off her austere nun’s dress. She turns it ins out, pulls here and there, undoes a seam, turns the nun’s dress inside out once again, and with a few enchanted gestures, the dress she now puts on is all white. She lay the white veil on her head in some gracious way.

dialogues.speaker: AGNES
dialogues.text: Now you can turn around. Shestan turns around and he is dazzled: Agnes smiles and beams in a totally white dress, the wedding dress she has magically improvised. He walks around her and helps her g on the mule. Agnes beams.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shestan and Agnes lie, turning their backs on each other. Moon is full. Shestan cannot sleep. Neither can Agnes. Th are both shy.

dialogues.speaker: SHESTAN
dialogues.text: Are you cold?

dialogues.speaker: AGNES
dialogues.text: No. Are you?

dialogues.speaker: SHESTAN
dialogues.text: No. Are you hungry? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: AGNES
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: SHESTAN
dialogues.text: Are you scared?

dialogues.speaker: AGNES
dialogues.text: Scared? I don’t know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They wake up in each other’s arms.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An old ottoman bridge, long and narrow. They cross the br both riding the mule. Peasants with carts pass them by, l at them, amused, and say hello.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shestan ties the mule to a pole and gives it some oats. People sitting outside a small café look at them with som curiosity. Shestan helps Agnes get off the mule and they walk to a shop on the door of which a sign reads:

dialogues.speaker: FOTOGRAF SOTIRI
dialogues.text: (Sotir, the Photographer) INT. PHOTOGRAPHER’S SHOP. DAY. 105 An incredible variety of photos are hanging on the walls: families, weddings, fighters. Shestan and Agnes look at t photographer’s hands, as he flips through some photos ina big box. Shestan seems forlorn. Sotir, the photographer, shrugs, puzzled.

dialogues.speaker: SOTIR
dialogues.text: That’s weird. It’s not here. Can’t find you, neither your bride.

dialogues.speaker: SHESTAN
dialogues.text: It’s not that kind of photo, sir. It’s a picture of me with my companions. You took it yourself, on the square, over there.

dialogues.speaker: SOTIR
dialogues.text: On the square? When was that?

dialogues.speaker: SHESTAN
dialogues.text: Some months ago, I don’t quite remember when. We had a canon and a mule with us. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: SOTIR
dialogues.text: Ah, yes! Now I remember! All the fuss you had to make! There you go! He points at a spot on the wall. Shestan looks at the wal and sees the photo with the familiar faces of Cute, Tod Doské, Alush, Méhill, Marko, Andrea, Tod, Aleksander, Hys and the others. They are all smiling and happy. Agnes get closer to have a look at the photo too. Shestan is frozen A heavy silence.

dialogues.speaker: SHESTAN
dialogues.text: I want a picture of me with my wife Shestan gives Sotir a gold coin. Sotir bites on it to che it.

Shestan, sitting in a wooden armchair, and Agnes with her hand on his shoulder, are being photographed. Shestan, fa camera, holds the picture of him and his friends in his l EXT. SHORE OF A GREAT LAKE - SOUTH-EASTERN ALBANIA. DAY. Shestan and Agnes wash hands and faces in the pure water the lake. Shestan looks at Agnes’ beautiful hands. He tak them in his hands and brings them to his lips.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They cross the pass between two mountains. Houses of a sm village appear in the distance, on the plateau.

dialogues.speaker: SHESTAN
dialogues.text: Look! This is my village. Over there! He points at the mountain. Agnes tries to find out the faraway village. She listens to him. SHESTAN (cont’d) One day you will go see your family again. You’1l take the mule and I’1l1 come with you. I have to give the mule back. This shepherd, he is a friend.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shestan walks along the crop fields, leading the mule wit Agnes on it. In the distance, he sees two men ploughing. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 94  109 110 s.108 p.95. These two stop working, and look at the man who is pullin the mule with the bride on it. They are Cute Benja and To Allamani. They made it to the village before Shestan.

dialogues.speaker: CUTE
dialogues.text: Tod, what kind of man would take a bride like this? Isn’t it strange?

dialogues.speaker: TOD
dialogues.text: Yes, sure, Cute, it is!

dialogues.speaker: CUTE
dialogues.text: How come there’s a wedding in the village and we know nothing? This is unheard of. They are taken aback. Can’t take their eyes off the man pulling the mule with the bride on it, but can’t recogniz him, he is too far away. Cute (cont'd) This guy must be nuts, bringing his bride over just like this, as if she was some game out of a hunt! Something must have happened. I can feel it. That’s the kind of thing I can feel from a long way off! Let’s finish this, and we go see what’s going on! They resume their ploughing. Shestan sees the two men wor in the field, but he cannot recognize his two friends, th are too far away. He pulls at the mule, and hurries up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shestan and Agnes arrive at the village. They stop.

dialogues.speaker: SHESTAN
dialogues.text: See, my house’s the one over there. You see the smoke? My mother must be inside. She most likely thinks I’m dead. He can barely hold his joy. Agnes adjusts the scarf. They ride on. Kids follow them and keep yelling.

dialogues.speaker: KIDS
dialogues.text: The bride, the bride, the bride! EXT. SHESTAN’S HOUSE. DAY. 110 Subtitle: 28 July 1914 (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 95  s.110 p.96. Shestan and Agnes are getting married. Everyone from the village is there, dancing and singing. A one-legged Cute comes in, holding on his crutches, followed by his childr and Tod. Cute raises his arm and music stops. Everyone lo at him.

dialogues.speaker: CUTE
dialogues.text: War, war has started. Silence. Shestan looks at him. Cute and Tod go to Shestan They shake hands and embrace. SHESTAN’S MOTHER Play the music. Loud! People start to sing and dance. Shestan, Cute and Tod rai toast.

dialogues.speaker: TOD
dialogues.text: War is coming, captain.

dialogues.speaker: CUTE
dialogues.text: War is coming, captain.

dialogues.speaker: SHESTAN
dialogues.text: To life! They drink, then Shestan takes them to dance. In the midd Cute holds on to their arms, and the three men dance toge like crazy. FORO IO I I Ae
